newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: RESULTS TODAY-CADSWEP SEEN UP ON DEMAND,ABI.
newsitem.headline: RESULTS TODAY-CADSWEP SEEN UP ON DEMAND,ABI.

text.p: South African drinks and sweets firm Cadbury Schweppes SA Ltd is set to post healthy half year growth, buoyed by good local demand and a windfall from a stake in Amalgamated Beverage Industries Ltd (ABI) , analysts said.
South Africans' taste for the firm's range of soft drinks and chocolate bars has not diminished despite a slow down in the broader economy.
"It has reasonable growth in this environment...volume growth has been good and it is a well-managed company," said one analyst who declined to be identified.
Analysts said the firm had impressed investors with a strong and successful marketing strategy and also benefitted from its top drawer brand names.
"It is a well managed company. They are doing well and they have very good products and brands," said another analyst.
Analysts are expecting interim earnings per share on a range of 17.2 cents to 17.6 and a dividend of 3.4 cents 3.5. The consensus figures were for earnings of 17.4 cents and a dividend of 3.44.
The figures compare to 146.6 and 29.0 cents respectively last time, but late last month the firm had a ten for one share split which dilutes profits per share by ten times.
Factoring in the share split leaves real earnings per share growth on a range of 17.3 to 20.1 percent.
The firm's shares, which started 1997 at 730 cents, have been climbing steadily all year and are now trading at 9.90 rand -- in real terms a firm gain on its pre-share split year high of 96.50 rand.
However, one analyst said he was concerned about the firm's gearing due a number of capital expenditure projects coming through into the balance sheet.
At it year results in March Cadswep said it expected real earnings growth in the current financial year. "Satisfactory real growth in earnings is expected to be achieved," the firm said then.
Cadswep owns a slice of bottler ABI and its earnings will get a lift from ABI's strong growth, which saw it in May lift year pre-tax profit to 201.4 million rand from 160.7 million last time.
Both Cadswep and ABI also stand to gain from the travails suffered by Pepsi's failed New Age Beverages (NAB) venture that is currently under provisional liquidation.
NAB's collapse should provide both firms with an opportunity to snap up extra market share, analysts said.
